bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, September 24, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D OCT 23 '01 DEPT. OF STATE

div1.p: No. 78. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, September 24, 1901.

p.add: Copy to Copy to Navy Ack Oct 26 1901

div1.p: Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. The reconstruction of the Lighthouse and the permanent establishment of the light on Cape Messorado, at the entrance of the harbor to Monrovia, Liberia complied.

p.add: ACKNOWLEDGED SEP 10 1901 Bureau of Foreign Commerce

div1.p: Consulate General of The United States, Monrovia Liberia; August 2, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.
Subject: Annual Letter for Commercial Relations of the United States.
No. 78. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, September 24, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to transmit the intelligence that the Lighthouse on Cape Messerado, at the entrance to Monrovia harbor (see report of Lieutenant W. P. White, of the U.S.S. Montgomery Oct. 18, 1899, as contained in [189] Africa. West coast Liberia, Monrovia harbor- Notice to Mariners No. 8, February 24, 1900) has been so far completed built of grey stone and mortar. Color of structure grey stone.

stone and mortar. White stationary light. The Lighthouse is reconstructed in the exact spot of old structure. See chart or reference above referred to, as I have no practicable means of obtaining the bearings &c, here.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
